div.head: Tour of 1825
div.p: In May 1825, the Ruskin family made its first visit to the Continent, a tour that was limited to Waterloo Field, Brussels, and Paris (including Versailles). As such, the journey was characteristically post‐Napoleonic. In his Diary, 1833–46, John James Ruskin reflects back on this 1825 journey, comparing their experiences during the much more ambitious Continental Tour of 1833. He notes that Paris on their present visit was “not so gay as in May 1825” (Diary of John James Ruskin,1833–46, 72, 73).

The journey may seem ambitious for a middle‐class London family, only recently established in their suburban home, and with a young boy; however, Channel crossings limited to the nearby and comparatively inexpensive destination of Belgium were common in the 1820s, and trips expressly to view the Waterloo battlefield had been popular since as early as the weeks following the battle itself. The popularity had been enhanced by personal visits paid by such well‐known literary figures as Walter Scott, Robert Southey, and Lord Byron (François, “If Itʼs 1815, This Must Be Belgium”, 74–75, 89). The year of the Ruskinsʼ crossing is noted as a watershed for middle‐class British travel by historians studying the opening of Netherlands, Belgium, and northern France, more rapid crossings having been made possible by the rise of steam packet lines. The steam lines greatly increased the efficiency, reliability, and carrying capacity for travelers who could take holidays from employment only for definite periods and on a limited budget. Presumably, the traveling party included Ruskinʼs nurse, Anne Strachan, who later accompanied the family also on the 1833 journey.

By the mid‐1820s, steam packets accommodated large excursion parties along with individual travelers, and the amenities included food and drink and even entertainment, with music performance being common onboard (Williams and Armstrong, “Steam Shipping and the Beginnings of Overseas Tourism”). For the Ruskinsʼ steam crossing seven years later, see Tour of 1833 and the glosses to “Calais” (prose).
